response.answer_text: Just about all the Pre-Classical composers of the so-called Baroque Age of European Culture who almost everybody hasn't heard of. So what this means to me is that the music schools are not doing their job in acquainting their music students with as many composers of the Baroque Period as possible besides Couperin, Vivaldi, Alessandro Scarlatti, Bach and Handel. So every other Baroque era composer has been made into not only a musician's musician but into a musician's, musician's musician or even a musician's, musician's, musician's musician. These then unknown composers by even other musicians are known only by musicologists. They are musicologists musicians. These musicologists musicians have written music that is vastly superior to most of the non-classical music being written today. I don't understand why people aren't flocking to the Baroque Era and constantly listening to all these Musicologist's Musicians that even professional Classical musicians have never heard of and seemingly never want to hear of and will even go out of their way not to hear of them. Other composers from the middle Baroque period are Constantin Christian Dedekind, Francesco Antonio Urio, and Carl Rosier. The middle Baroque period is when many of the mature Baroque musical forms were evolved so that the music always sounds up to date. Before the middle Baroque period the music can sound antiquated, but then again, Gregorian Chant sounds great and that predates middle Baroque by 600 years. By the late Baroque period( those composers born 1650 and after) the forms, instruments and virtuosity were well established and the composers could go on to write and perform the most glorious music ever written and improvised on. Improvisation was required in the Baroque period. If a musician could not improvise they were not really considered full musicians, in fact the ability to improvise was a pre-requisite to wanting to be and being a musician. We will never be able to hear the improvisations of the best improvisers of the Baroque period since nothing was recorded because the recording technology was not invented yet. What we can hope for is for Hiromi Uehara, to one by one pick several compositions by each of the composers she picks and improvise on their written works. She must be the equal of the ever praised Baroque improvisers and the great improvisers of the Classical period and the Romantic period, before Classical Music got stultified by an avoidance of improvisation which is the origin and lifeblood of Music.
